intro: Copiapoa cinerea, commonly known as the pale copiapoa, is a species of cactus native to the Atacama Desert in Chile. It is characterized by its cylindrical stems that are covered in a whitish, powdery coating, which helps reflect sunlight and reduce water loss. The plant produces white or pale yellow flowers during the cooler months, typically in spring. It is a slow-growing species that thrives in well-drained soils and requires minimal water. Copiapoa cinerea is often cultivated as a ornamental plant due to its unique appearance and adaptability to arid environments.
